source.ef7cdc06:
print(f"The earliest publish time the data have is {us_trending['publish_time'].min()}")
print(f"The latest publish time the data have is {us_trending['publish_time'].max()}")
range_days = (pd.to_datetime(us_trending['publish_time'].max())-pd.to_datetime(us_trending['publish_time'].min())).days
print(f"Range of publish time our data has is {range_days} days or equal to {range_days/365} years")
source.18d7905e:
us_trending["like_dislike_ratio"] = us_trending["likes"]/us_trending["dislikes"]

#the smaller the ratio is the more the bigger the dislike is relative to like
us_trending.sort_values("like_dislike_ratio").head(20)[us_trending.columns.difference(['video_id', 'category_id','publish_time','tags','thumbnail_link','description'])]
source.5884d6c3:
more_disliked = us_trending[us_trending["dislikes"] > us_trending["likes"]]
print(f"There are {len(more_disliked)} trending videos which is around {round(len(more_disliked)/len(us_trending)*100,2)}% of the trending videos")
source.1b542c84:
more_liked = us_trending[us_trending["dislikes"] <= us_trending["likes"]]
p_dis = len(more_disliked[more_disliked["comments_disabled"] == True]) / len(more_disliked) 
print(f"The probability of a videos comment section to be disabled given it has more dislikes is {round(p_dis*100,2)}%")
p_like = len(more_liked[more_liked["comments_disabled"] == True]) / len(more_liked) 
print(f"The probability of a videos comment section to be disabled given it has more or equal ratio of likes and dislikes is {round(p_like*100,2)}%")
print(f"So videos with more dislikes are {round(p_dis/p_like,1)} times more likely to disable their comment section !!")

source.da9b709c:
Looks like video_id is our primary key. 
As we can see there are not a lot of null values. Description Column is the only column that has couple hundreds of null values. For now we are not going to drop the rosewood null values in description because a lot of power query will not use description anyway.
source.099ec6ff: ### 2. As we might have known, not everything that are popular are also likeable. Some things are popular because there are so much hatred towards it. Personally I heard that youtube algorithm doesn't only share video with a lot of likes, they share video with a lot of engagement, and dislike is one form of engagement. So let's see if there are videos in our dataset that have more dislikes than likes. If there are, what is the ratio of heavily disliked videos?

It seems like the top 20 most disliked trending videos are from just a few youtube channel. If we look closely there are quite a lot of videos with comments disabled in there. This leads to the next question which is

### 3. How much more likely for a dislikeable videos(more dislikes than likes) to disabled their comment section?
